body:
I've done mostly C# in the past 3 years, but I've started working on a major typescript project last week and it has been nothing short of a nightmare.

- TS lets you specify types at compile-time, this information is lost on JS and it is entirely possible for some pure-js library to give you the wrong type.
- If and when this happens, you will have a hard time figuring out where it happened, because the stacktrace from the exception gives you line numbers in javascript, which don't correspond to what I wrote.
- I can't imagine that a language which is interpreted with every request is competitive, in terms of speed, to a compiled language like C#. (Unless the JS gets compiled into native code when the server starts, which would be similar to what C# does.)

And that's just the one ridiculous problem that I've been dealing with for the last 30 minutes. I'm having an extremely hard time getting anything done because I'm constantly confronted with some problem that never would have happened in C#.

Maybe it's just me being resistant to so many foreign concepts at once, but I feel like I'm just scratching the surface of the insanity. This is an honest, serious question to any Typescript dev that reads this: why do you use typescript?
body_html:
I've done mostly C# in the past 3 years, but I've started working on a major typescript project last week and it has been nothing short of a nightmare.

  • TS lets you specify types at compile-time, this information is lost on JS and it is entirely possible for some pure-js library to give you the wrong type.
  • If and when this happens, you will have a hard time figuring out where it happened, because the stacktrace from the exception gives you line numbers in javascript, which don't correspond to what I wrote.
  • I can't imagine that a language which is interpreted with every request is competitive, in terms of speed, to a compiled language like C#. (Unless the JS gets compiled into native code when the server starts, which would be similar to what C# does.)

And that's just the one ridiculous problem that I've been dealing with for the last 30 minutes. I'm having an extremely hard time getting anything done because I'm constantly confronted with some problem that never would have happened in C#.

Maybe it's just me being resistant to so many foreign concepts at once, but I feel like I'm just scratching the surface of the insanity. This is an honest, serious question to any Typescript dev that reads this: why do you use typescript?

body: I only use it for the web because I have no choice. Its that or Javascript afaik, and type script makes things easier due to the data types and other elements. My company works with Angular so we're married to TypeScript and it may also be that we're just used to it.

post.title: [Serious] Why would you use typescript

body:
* I've never found incorrect typings for a js library I've used. I'm sure they exist for less popular libraries but they're infrequent and easy to fix.

* If you include source mappings in your dev build tsconfig this should tell you where the problem is in your typescript.

* I don't get what you mean here. I only use it for browser stuff where the only other option is js (yeah yeah, wasm is coming, but until then...). If you want better performance use something else. Typescript is not meant to be performant. Use the right tool for the right job.

A huge benefit of using typescript, in the browser at least, is when it's being transpiled to js you can polyfill stuff. For example: say you use a feature that isn't available in ie11, when it's being transpiled to js it will be replaced with something that works on browsers you're targeting in your tsconfig.

Also it's a lot easier to write typescript with the familiar classes & interfaces syntax and have the transpiler work out the prototypes syntax for js. (I guess js has `class` now but it's still a bit weird)

But really the main benefit is just catching errors at transpile time rather than runtime. Typescripts types like `number | undefined` has save me more than once.
body_html:
• I've never found incorrect typings for a js library I've used. I'm sure they exist for less popular libraries but they're infrequent and easy to fix.

  • If you include source mappings in your dev build tsconfig this should tell you where the problem is in your typescript.

  • I don't get what you mean here. I only use it for browser stuff where the only other option is js (yeah yeah, wasm is coming, but until then...). If you want better performance use something else. Typescript is not meant to be performant. Use the right tool for the right job.

A huge benefit of using typescript, in the browser at least, is when it's being transpiled to js you can polyfill stuff. For example: say you use a feature that isn't available in ie11, when it's being transpiled to js it will be replaced with something that works on browsers you're targeting in your tsconfig.

Also it's a lot easier to write typescript with the familiar classes & interfaces syntax and have the transpiler work out the prototypes syntax for js. (I guess js has class now but it's still a bit weird)

But really the main benefit is just catching errors at transpile time rather than runtime. Typescripts types like number | undefined has save me more than once.

post.title: [Serious] Why would you use typescript

body:
I probably should've said this in the OP but I'm talking about a project where typescript is being used server-side. There is the freedom to run any application framework. You're right, I'm not sure if there are any other good options for client-side scripting.

The issue I was facing is with an xlsx library which seems to be written in JS with a TS wrapper. I give it an anonymous type to deserialize the data into, which is all the necessary values with `string` as their types. When I read a row, the phone number (which will be written as "+123456789" in the xlsx file) comes back as a number, despite all the types being strings. I thought this is because JS doesn't know what types I specified in TS, so it just gives me whatever seems appropriate. The fix is to call .toString on the number, but it could have easily been avoided in another language.

I'll try including source mappings. Thanks!
body_html:
I probably should've said this in the OP but I'm talking about a project where typescript is being used server-side. There is the freedom to run any application framework. You're right, I'm not sure if there are any other good options for client-side scripting.

The issue I was facing is with an xlsx library which seems to be written in JS with a TS wrapper. I give it an anonymous type to deserialize the data into, which is all the necessary values with string as their types. When I read a row, the phone number (which will be written as "+123456789" in the xlsx file) comes back as a number, despite all the types being strings. I thought this is because JS doesn't know what types I specified in TS, so it just gives me whatever seems appropriate. The fix is to call .toString on the number, but it could have easily been avoided in another language.

I'll try including source mappings. Thanks!

parent.body:
* I've never found incorrect typings for a js library I've used. I'm sure they exist for less popular libraries but they're infrequent and easy to fix.

* If you include source mappings in your dev build tsconfig this should tell you where the problem is in your typescript.

* I don't get what you mean here. I only use it for browser stuff where the only other option is js (yeah yeah, wasm is coming, but until then...). If you want better performance use something else. Typescript is not meant to be performant. Use the right tool for the right job.

A huge benefit of using typescript, in the browser at least, is when it's being transpiled to js you can polyfill stuff. For example: say you use a feature that isn't available in ie11, when it's being transpiled to js it will be replaced with something that works on browsers you're targeting in your tsconfig.

Also it's a lot easier to write typescript with the familiar classes & interfaces syntax and have the transpiler work out the prototypes syntax for js. (I guess js has `class` now but it's still a bit weird)

But really the main benefit is just catching errors at transpile time rather than runtime. Typescripts types like `number | undefined` has save me more than once.

  • I don't get what you mean here. I only use it for browser stuff where the only other option is js (yeah yeah, wasm is coming, but until then...). If you want better performance use something else. Typescript is not meant to be performant. Use the right tool for the right job.

A huge benefit of using typescript, in the browser at least, is when it's being transpiled to js you can polyfill stuff. For example: say you use a feature that isn't available in ie11, when it's being transpiled to js it will be replaced with something that works on browsers you're targeting in your tsconfig.

Also it's a lot easier to write typescript with the familiar classes & interfaces syntax and have the transpiler work out the prototypes syntax for js. (I guess js has class now but it's still a bit weird)

But really the main benefit is just catching errors at transpile time rather than runtime. Typescripts types like number | undefined has save me more than once.

post.title: [Serious] Why would you use typescript

body:
> TS lets you specify types at compile-time, this information is lost on JS and it is entirely possible for some pure-js library to give you the wrong type

You definitely shouldn't get the wrong type. You _might_ if you've installed a version of `xxx` but a different version of `@types/xxx`, and that only applies to libs that don't provide their own types. I've maybe had this happen _once_ ever.

> If and when this happens, you will have a hard time figuring out where it happened, because the stacktrace from the exception gives you line numbers in javascript, which don't correspond to what I wrote

Enable source maps. With source maps enabled, and an environment that knows what they are, you'll be directed to the exact line in TS. This even works in browsers for client-side JS - the Chrome dev tools will recognize the .map file and direct you to the correct place in the .ts file.

This same issue applies not only to Typescript but to anything that runs through a compiler like webpack or babel. If you're doing front-end stuff, you should be using one of those anyway. If you're using node, then yeah, tsc is probably the only compiler you're using.

Locally, you can always run `ts-node` and skip the source map step. That might help.

If you're doing front-end development in React or Angular (two that I know of), you'll get useful errors by default in dev mode.

> I can't imagine that a language which is interpreted with every request is competitive, in terms of speed, to a compiled language like C#. (Unless the JS gets compiled into native code when the server starts, which would be similar to what C# does.)

It's not as fast as compiled, but in my line of work, I've never hit a situation where that mattered. If I'm writing an HTTP API that has a database back end, then the HTTP connection time, database connection time, and database query time will all take longer (by an order of magnitude) than any extra juice you can squeeze out by the code being native-compiled.

> why do you use typescript?

1. Better intellisense. My editor can suggest property names and methods a lot easier when it knows what the type of a variable is, what arguments a function expects, etc.
2. Compile time errors are always better than runtime errors. If the compiler can catch a mistake now, that's a lot better than catching a mistake later, especially if it's a case missed by my unit tests.
3. Compiling "down". It's not a huge issue in node when I know my code will by run in node 12+, but when I'm writing stuff for browser consumption I can set the compiler to ES5 or something and get good browser compatibility but still use modern things like async and await.
body_html:
TS lets you specify types at compile-time, this information is lost on JS and it is entirely possible for some pure-js library to give you the wrong type

You definitely shouldn't get the wrong type. You might if you've installed a version of xxx but a different version of @types/xxx, and that only applies to libs that don't provide their own types. I've maybe had this happen once ever.

If and when this happens, you will have a hard time figuring out where it happened, because the stacktrace from the exception gives you line numbers in javascript, which don't correspond to what I wrote

Enable source maps. With source maps enabled, and an environment that knows what they are, you'll be directed to the exact line in TS. This even works in browsers for client-side JS - the Chrome dev tools will recognize the .map file and direct you to the correct place in the .ts file.

This same issue applies not only to Typescript but to anything that runs through a compiler like webpack or babel. If you're doing front-end stuff, you should be using one of those anyway. If you're using node, then yeah, tsc is probably the only compiler you're using.

Locally, you can always run ts-node and skip the source map step. That might help.

If you're doing front-end development in React or Angular (two that I know of), you'll get useful errors by default in dev mode.

I can't imagine that a language which is interpreted with every request is competitive, in terms of speed, to a compiled language like C#. (Unless the JS gets compiled into native code when the server starts, which would be similar to what C# does.)

It's not as fast as compiled, but in my line of work, I've never hit a situation where that mattered. If I'm writing an HTTP API that has a database back end, then the HTTP connection time, database connection time, and database query time will all take longer (by an order of magnitude) than any extra juice you can squeeze out by the code being native-compiled.

why do you use typescript?

  1. Better intellisense. My editor can suggest property names and methods a lot easier when it knows what the type of a variable is, what arguments a function expects, etc.
  2. Compile time errors are always better than runtime errors. If the compiler can catch a mistake now, that's a lot better than catching a mistake later, especially if it's a case missed by my unit tests.
  3. Compiling "down". It's not a huge issue in node when I know my code will by run in node 12+, but when I'm writing stuff for browser consumption I can set the compiler to ES5 or something and get good browser compatibility but still use modern things like async and await.

I probably should've said this in the OP but I'm talking about a project where typescript is being used server-side. There is the freedom to run any application framework. You're right, I'm not sure if there are any other good options for client-side scripting.

The issue I was facing is with an xlsx library which seems to be written in JS with a TS wrapper. I give it an anonymous type to deserialize the data into, which is all the necessary values with `string` as their types. When I read a row, the phone number (which will be written as "+123456789" in the xlsx file) comes back as a number, despite all the types being strings. I thought this is because JS doesn't know what types I specified in TS, so it just gives me whatever seems appropriate. The fix is to call .toString on the number, but it could have easily been avoided in another language.

I'll try including source mappings. Thanks!
parent.body_html:
I probably should've said this in the OP but I'm talking about a project where typescript is being used server-side. There is the freedom to run any application framework. You're right, I'm not sure if there are any other good options for client-side scripting.

The issue I was facing is with an xlsx library which seems to be written in JS with a TS wrapper. I give it an anonymous type to deserialize the data into, which is all the necessary values with string as their types. When I read a row, the phone number (which will be written as "+123456789" in the xlsx file) comes back as a number, despite all the types being strings. I thought this is because JS doesn't know what types I specified in TS, so it just gives me whatever seems appropriate. The fix is to call .toString on the number, but it could have easily been avoided in another language.

I'll try including source mappings. Thanks!

post.body:
I've done mostly C# in the past 3 years, but I've started working on a major typescript project last week and it has been nothing short of a nightmare.

- TS lets you specify types at compile-time, this information is lost on JS and it is entirely possible for some pure-js library to give you the wrong type.
- If and when this happens, you will have a hard time figuring out where it happened, because the stacktrace from the exception gives you line numbers in javascript, which don't correspond to what I wrote.
- I can't imagine that a language which is interpreted with every request is competitive, in terms of speed, to a compiled language like C#. (Unless the JS gets compiled into native code when the server starts, which would be similar to what C# does.)

And that's just the one ridiculous problem that I've been dealing with for the last 30 minutes. I'm having an extremely hard time getting anything done because I'm constantly confronted with some problem that never would have happened in C#.

Maybe it's just me being resistant to so many foreign concepts at once, but I feel like I'm just scratching the surface of the insanity. This is an honest, serious question to any Typescript dev that reads this: why do you use typescript?
post.body_html:
I've done mostly C# in the past 3 years, but I've started working on a major typescript project last week and it has been nothing short of a nightmare.

  • TS lets you specify types at compile-time, this information is lost on JS and it is entirely possible for some pure-js library to give you the wrong type.
  • If and when this happens, you will have a hard time figuring out where it happened, because the stacktrace from the exception gives you line numbers in javascript, which don't correspond to what I wrote.
  • I can't imagine that a language which is interpreted with every request is competitive, in terms of speed, to a compiled language like C#. (Unless the JS gets compiled into native code when the server starts, which would be similar to what C# does.)

And that's just the one ridiculous problem that I've been dealing with for the last 30 minutes. I'm having an extremely hard time getting anything done because I'm constantly confronted with some problem that never would have happened in C#.

Maybe it's just me being resistant to so many foreign concepts at once, but I feel like I'm just scratching the surface of the insanity. This is an honest, serious question to any Typescript dev that reads this: why do you use typescript?
post.title: [Serious] Why would you use typescript
